description: Mark Ellingson, President of the Rochester Athenaeum & Mechanics Institute (RAMI) takes over the Empire State School of Printing located in Ithaca, New York, and it becomes a two-year program.
20 freshman enroll in the program with the first major printing project by the department being the student newspaper, PSIMAR.
Students take over the editorial page of the Democrat and Chronicle for one issue.
Rochester Athenaeum & Mechanics Institute becomes Rochester Institute of Technology.
SPM moves into Clark Building with enrollment dramatically increasing to 136 due to the end of WWII.
First 4-color illustration appears in Student Publication, Rochester Institute of Technology (SPRIT)

RIT and the Lithographic Technical Foundation sponsor a Web Offset Conference and propose a new web press purchase for the school. Gannett Company donates a Teletypesetter system to the School of Printing.
SPRIT changes its name to RIT Reporter.
One-third of seniors major in offset lithography; two-thirds major in letterpress printing. Frank Gannett is presented the prestigious Founders Award for his service to the Institute.
Ellen Eggleton becomes the first woman to receive an Associate of Applied from the School of Printing.
Printing students Carl Nelson and Arthur Borock convince the Athletic Board to adopt the tiger emblem to represent RIT sports.
A section of the Hand Composition Laboratory is dedicated in memoriam to prominent typography, Frederic W. Goudy.
Flexography and gravure printing become part of the curriculum.
New Goss C-38 publication press is installed on the campus.
Melbert B. Cary Jr., Graphic Arts Collection is donated, housing historical and current examples of “fine” printing.

250 freshman enter the program making the total number enrolled an impressive 661 students. MBO folding machine for bindery is donated. Now all major printing processes are represented with up-to-date equipment.
150th Anniversary of RIT
Renovation and rededication of the Cary Graphic Arts Collection is finished.
Labs are updated with $4.2 million in computer equipment.
A SCR-40 Scanning densitometer, a Linotype/Paul scanner, and a Compugraphics typesetter are donated.
Cary Library no longer has a “look but don’t touch” policy and is open for use.
The newspaper production lab that supported the degree program, News Paper Operations Management, begins using a digital page layout system.
New Media courses are first offered as part of SPM curriculum.
The Digital Publishing Center is established, printing student work at RIT.

RIT is selected by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to become one of twenty-six Sloan Industry Centers. This center is dedicated to studying major business environment influences in the printing industry.
The Printing Applications Lab at RIT is donated a Sunday 2000 press.
Open Publishing Lab is founded, researching new methods of content creation and developing open source applications for publishing across various media.
75th Anniversary of the School of Print Media.
